page.title: 20Local History (Cont.)
page.content: house for wayfarers and the open-armed figure outside was presented to Vera as a symbol of the open door which was part of her faith. With the coming of modern amenities most settlers asked for legal rights to their land and were inclined to sell their now "desirable property" and drift back to the world they once deserted. Vera married, giving the remaining land to her artist husband and the name of his estate became known as "Sleepy Hollow". He built the shelter to give tired pedestrians a chance to rest while enshrining the Sanctuary where a very simple Christian gesture caused such interest.
